pageTitle: Mayor's funding boost for local transport improvements in Sutton

title.title: Mayor's funding boost for local transport improvements in Sutton

texts: The Mayor of London confirmed £1.8m from Transport for London (TfL) to make much-needed improvements to transport for Sutton.
Sutton receives funding from TfL each year as part of the Local Implementation Plan (LIP) allocated to the London boroughs to fund local projects which support the Mayor's Transport Strategy.

These include improvements to local town centres and public spaces, new cycling facilities, safer roads and measures to smooth traffic flow.

Today's funding announcement of £1.8m for Sutton will mean the vast majority of the borough's proposed schemes for 2011/12 will be delivered.

To support this, the Mayor has given greater flexibility to the borough so that they can prioritise projects according to local need.

Following the Government's Comprehensive Spending Review, the funding allocated to London boroughs will fall over the next three years to reflect the reduced grant TfL receives from the Department for Transport.

However, the funding for programmes such as road maintenance, bridge strengthening, major schemes and the borough discretionary fund have all been safeguarded.

Funding to benefit all Londoners, is also being made available for modernising traffic signals and partnership initiatives such as completion of the London Strategic Walking Network.

Mayor of London, Boris Johnson, said: 'This funding will allow the boroughs to make real improvements to town centres, provide better cycling facilities and make roads safer across the Capital.

'I'm especially pleased we have been able to cut the red tape that used to surround these schemes and give the boroughs more freedom to choose how they want to spend money to improve their local communities.'

Sutton has been developing proposals on a number of schemes it will be financing from the funding package, including:

{"template":"bulletlist","items":["£660,00 towards the Wallington Integrated Transport Package - a ground-breaking pilot project to find ways to make walking, cycling and taking other forms of public transport the easiest option for local residents; measures include research and promotion of local 'sustainable' journeys that offer as good a service as travelling by car","£150,000 towards the Beddington Lane Regeneration Project which will include upgrading the 2km stretch of road and improve accessibility to the Industrial Estate.  The works will also promote sustainable modes of transport with a shared pedestrian and cycle route and additional bus stops will be added to improve links to the tram and existing bus stops will be improved for people with disabilities","£100,000 towards a borough-wide cycle training scheme aimed principally at primary and secondary schools, but with some adult training too"]}

London's Transport Commissioner, Peter Hendy, said: 'Delivering the Mayor's vision for transport in London is an ambitious task and it is essential we work in partnership with the London boroughs to make it happen.
'This investment will play a significant role in continuing to improve transport across the Capital.'
